text: anger and sadness in Tianjin local
residents of the blast site demand
compensation and answers from the
government saying many of their homes
were ruined by the explosion by our
homes back they shout so far the
government hasn't given us any kind of
reasonable response and they haven't
been paying attention to what we have to
say so at the moment we feel all over
the place
smoke still rises from the blast site
now the center of a major cleanup
operation there's concern that Chinese
work safety rules may have been breached
chemical facilities are required to be
at least a thousand meters away from
residences through high international
warehouse was only 500 metres from an
apartment block and this is the man
who'll have some difficult questions to
answer
Premier Li Keqiang visited the area on
Sunday and paid his respects at a
memorial before visiting a hospital he
said that anyone who acted illegally
would be severely punished a hundred and
fourteen people have now been confirmed
dead with a further 70 missing
China's emergency services took a heavy
hit sixty-four of those still
unaccounted for are firefighters
but this too has also raised concerns
after reports that some of those first
on the scene may have used water to
douse the flames something which can
cause sodium cyanide to explode with so
much controversy brewing and so much
pain for those affected the
investigation into one of China's
deadliest industrial accidents will need
to find answers fast
James Longman BBC News
